categories.title: basics
categories.description: Techniques and best practices for basic components of web applications.

components.title: basics
components.description: Here are some general techniques that are useful for a variety of components and usecases.

components.title: colors
components.description: Colors are a very important topic. These best practices help you to make sure that your color palette is useful also for people with low vision or color blindness.

components.title: document
components.description: There are some basic things you ensure to make your application or website accessible.

components.title: footer
components.description: Footers are an important landmark and belong to the main structure of your document.

components.title: header
components.description: Headers are an important landmark and belong to the main structure of your document.

components.title: language
components.description: Missing language information makes up for 18.6% of all accessibility failures. To fix this is really simple. Here are some techniques that will help you.

components.title: main
components.description: The main element is an important landmark and belongs to the main structure of your document.

components.title: title
components.description: Document titles are often the first thing user enounter.

components.title: breadcrumbs
components.description: With the complexity of many websites and apps today, it can be easy to lose track of where you are. Breadcrumbs serve as a guiding mechanism, allowing users to seamlessly progress through multi-page websites. Users with disabilities can benefit from structured and well-designed navigations, reducing confusion and frustration. Informing people of where they are within a set of pages is accessible to those with cognitive and attention- related disorders.

components.title: links
components.description: Links are one of the biggest sources for accessibility failures. 50% of all websites contain empty links. These are links that have no accessible information about their purpose, like for example a link with just an icon and no alternative text. This means that a person who uses a screen reader or braille displays just knows that there is a link but not what it does.

components.title: multi-step
components.description: With the complexity of many websites and apps today, it can be easy to lose track of where you are. Multi-step indicators serve as a guiding mechanism, allowing users to seamlessly progress through multi-step processes.

components.title: accordions
components.description: Accordions are a great way to keep your UI clean and tidy. Accordions are great to reduce the need to scroll when presenting multiple sections of content on a single page. Here are some techniques that help to ensure that information is available to a wider range of users.

components.title: charts
components.description: Chart and data are a very important topic for accessibility. Very often they are presented in a way that is not accessible to assistive technologies like screen readers. Which by the way also means that it is not accessible to search engines.

components.title: headings
components.description: Headings create an outline for the page, similar to a term paper outline or table of contents.

components.title: icons
components.description: Icons can transport a lot of information. The following techniques ensure that this information is also accessible when using assistive technologies like screen readers or braille keyboards.

components.title: images
components.description: Images are an important element of a user interface and storytelling . They provide context and orientation. The following techniques ensure that this information is also accessible when using assistive technologies like screen readers or braille keyboards.

components.title: lists
components.description: HTML lists convey a hierarchical content structure.

components.title: text
components.description: Content is king. This is also a good reason why you should make sure that the king is accessible for everyone. A good color contrast and font-size ensures that your audience actually can read the content. Even if the sun shines on their monitor.

components.title: tooltips
components.description: Tooltips display additional information upon hover or focus that is contextual, helpful, and nonessential while providing the ability to communicate and give clarity to a user.

components.title: buttons
components.description: Here is a list of techniques to ensure that buttons are useful for individuals with disabilities, visible or invisible and in different situations. They also help to ensure that buttons can be used with keyboard only and with assistive technologies like screen readers or braille keyboards.
